title: Charles Edward Nicholson
text:
Charles Edward Nicholson (1854 – 24 September 1931) was an Australian politician.
He was born in West <a href="Maitland%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Maitland</a> to grazier William Nicholson and Mary Ann Ryan. He was a solicitor's clerk before joining the <a href="Newcastle%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newcastle</a> post office in 1876, soon rising to assistant postmaster and then postmaster in 1880. From 1882 he was crown lands agent at <a href="Coonabarabran">Coonabarabran</a>; he resigned in 1888 to return to Maitland to farm. He served in the <a href="Boer%20War">Boer War</a> as a <a href="captain%20%28armed%20services%29">captain</a> and was <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">mentioned in despatches</a> three times. He was elected to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Legislative%20Assembly">New South Wales Legislative Assembly</a> in 1911 as the <a href="Liberal%20Reform%20Party%20%28Australia%29">Liberal</a> member for <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Maitland">Maitland</a>. During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> he served with the Hunter River Lancers and the <a href="Australian%20Light%20Horse">Australian Light Horse</a> as a <a href="major%20%28rank%29">major</a> and then on Sea Transport staff from 1916 to 1917 as a <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a>. He was defeated in 1920, and after another unsuccessful run in 1925 retired from politics. Nicholson died in Maitland in 1931.
